00031 class Cell {
00032 //    friend class MCGeometry;
00033 public:
00035     //  as viewed from this cell
00036     typedef std::pair<Quadric*, bool>          QuadricAndSense;
00038     typedef std::vector<QuadricAndSense>       QASVec;
00040     typedef std::vector<Cell*>                 CellVec;
00041 
00043     Cell(const QASVec& boundingSurfaces, const unsigned int userId = 0) 
00044         : _boundingSurfaces(boundingSurfaces),
00045           _userId(userId)
00046     {
00047         Require(_boundingSurfaces.size() > 0);
00048 
00049         // initialize hood map
00050         QASVec::const_iterator bsIt = _boundingSurfaces.begin();
00051         typedef std::pair<HoodMap::iterator, bool> ReturnedPair;
00052 
00053         while (bsIt != _boundingSurfaces.end()) {
00054             ReturnedPair result = 
00055                 _hood.insert(std::make_pair(bsIt->first, CellVec()));
00056 
00057             Insist(result.second == true, "Duplicate surface in this cell.");
00058             ++bsIt;
00059         }
00060     }
00061 
00063     ~Cell() {
00064 //        cout << "Oh no, I (cell " << this << ") am dying!" << endl;
00065         /* * */
00066     }
00067 
00069     //  instead?
00070     const QASVec& getBoundingSurfaces() const {
00071         return _boundingSurfaces;
00072     }
00073 
00075     //  non-const so that whatever we pass can add to it
00076     //  TODO possibly poor design here?
00077     //const CellVec& getNeighbors(const Quadric* surface) const {
00078     CellVec& getNeighbors(Quadric* surface) {
00079         // I think surface can't be const because findResult returns a pair
00080         // that has a non-const Quadric* in it
00081         HoodMap::iterator findResult = _hood.find(surface);
00082         Require(findResult != _hood.end());
00083 
00084         return findResult->second;
00085     }
00086 
00088     const unsigned int getUserId() const {
00089         return _userId;
00090     }

00095     //}

00098     //         testing "next region"
00099     // do this by comparing the "sense" of each of our surface to what the
00100     // surface says about the position's sense relative to it
00101     bool isPointInside(const std::vector<double>& position,
00102                        const Quadric* surfaceToSkip = NULL) const;
00103 
00105     void intersect( const std::vector<double>& position,

00124 /*----------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00125 inline bool Cell::isPointInside(const std::vector<double>& position,
00126                                 const Quadric* surfaceToSkip) const
00127 {
00128     // loop over all surfaces
00129     for (QASVec::const_iterator it = _boundingSurfaces.begin();
00130                                       it != _boundingSurfaces.end(); ++it)
00131     {
00132         // it->first is the pointer to the Quadric object
00133         // it->second is the surface sense
00134         
00135         // if we need to check it
00136         if (it->first != surfaceToSkip)
00137         {
00138            if ( it->first->hasPosSense(position) != it->second ) {
00139                // if the surface reports that the sense of the point is 
00140                // NOT the same sense as we know this cell is defined, then
00141                // it is not inside.
00142                return false;
00143            }
00144         }
00145     }
00146     // we only get to this point if the point has the correct sense wrt every
00147     // surface that we checked
00148     return true;
00149 }
00150 /*----------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
00151 inline void Cell::intersect(
00152                     const std::vector<double>& position,
00153                     const std::vector<double>& direction,
00154                     Quadric*& hitQuadric,
00155                     bool&     quadricSense,
00156                     double&   distance) const
00157 {
00158     //since we only *pass* these variables to the lower level and don't actually
00159     //base anything on their properties in this function; let the lower level
00160     //handle the input checking instead of being redundant by including it here
00161     //and at MCGeometry
00162 //    Require(position.size() == 3);
00163 //    Require(direction.size() == 3);
00164 
00165     hitQuadric   = NULL;
00166     quadricSense = false;
00167     distance     = std::numeric_limits<double>::infinity();
00168 
00169     // loop over all surfaces
00170     for (QASVec::const_iterator it =  _boundingSurfaces.begin();
00171                                 it != _boundingSurfaces.end(); ++it)
00172     {
00173         // call "intersect" on the quadric, also passing our sense 
00174         // of the quadric (it->second)
00175         Quadric::HitAndDist theResult = 
00176             it->first->intersect(position, direction, it->second);
00177 
00178         // if this check fails, then two surfaces apparently have exactly the
00179         // same distance from the particle; i.e. the particle ran into a corner?
00180         // what happens then?
00181 //        Check(theResult.second != distance);
00182 
00183 //        cout << "Test for " << typeid(*(it->first)).name()
00184 //             << ": hit=" << theResult.first << " dist=" << theResult.second
00185 //             << endl;
00186 
00187         if (theResult.first // if it hits, and if it's a smaller distance
00188                 && (theResult.second < distance))
00189         {
00190             distance     = theResult.second;
00191             hitQuadric   = it->first;
00192             quadricSense = it->second;
00193         }
00194     }
00195 
00196     // really do this? yes, if intersect is only called if isInsideCell is a
00197     // certainty
00198     Ensure(hitQuadric != NULL);
00199     Ensure(distance   != std::numeric_limits<double>::infinity());
00200 }
